abstract.t: This specification describes a new property for vCard Format Specification to allow the specification of objectclasses.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: The objectclass concept is used in ldap to allow the specification of a set of properties which describe a given type of object. For example, a schedulable entity MUST contain a calendar user address and the absence of the AUTOSCHEDULE property implies certain defaults.

An ldap objectclass may be of 3 kinds, structural, abstract and auxiliary. The vcard KIND property is equivalent to the structural objectclass in that a vcard can be of only one kind. The kind requires that certain properties be present and also defines defaults for absent properties.
The OBJECTCLASS property defined here is equivalent in many ways to the auxiliary objectclass in ldap. They are not related to each other in some hierarchy and may overlap in their use of properties.
Objectclass definitions can only specify properties which MUST, SHOULD or MAY be present. They cannot disallow the use of properties as these may be required by another objectclass.

section.title: Conventions Used in This Document
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in .

section.title: Objectclass Property
section.t: Format and cardinality of new vCard properties are defined as described in Section 3.3 of .

list.t: To specify the objectclass for this vcard.
This property MAY be present 1 or more times. For each occurrence of the property the vcard MUST conform to the specification for that objectclass.

section.title: Examples
section.t: These examples do not draw on any currently defined objectclass but are intended to indicate some uses. Properties used here may not be defined in any specification.

section.title: Eduperson vcard
section.t: The eduperson ldap objectclass provides for a number of attributes considered useful for interaction between members of educational organizations. A corresponding vcard objectclass would allow for better mappping of ldap directories onto a vcard representation.

figure.preamble: The 201203 specification of the LDAP objectclass for reference. Note that all attributes are MAY so would have a vcard cardinality of *1 or *.
figure.artwork: ( 1.3.6.1.4.1.5923.1.1.2 NAME 'eduPerson' AUXILIARY MAY ( eduPersonAffiliation $ eduPersonNickname $ eduPersonOrgDN $ eduPersonOrgUnitDN $ eduPersonPrimaryAffiliation $ eduPersonPrincipalName $ eduPersonEntitlement $ eduPersonPrimaryOrgUnitDN $ eduPersonScopedAffiliation $ eduPersonTargetedID $ eduPersonAssurance)

figure.preamble: A vcard mapping would, where possible use existing vcard properties. Where not possible new properties could be defined.
figure.artwork: BEGIN:VCARD VERSION:4.0 UID:urn:uuid:4fbe8971-0bc3-424c-9c26-36c3e1eff6b1 FN:J. Doe N:Doe;J.;;; EMAIL:jdoe@example.edu TEL;VALUE=uri:tel:+1-555-555-5555 OBJECTCLASS:eduperson NICKNAME:Jack ORGDN: dc=example, dc=edu AFFILIATION;TYPE=primary:faculty AFFILIATION;TYPE=scoped:faculty@cs.example.edu END:VCARD

section.title: Schedulable
section.t: A schedulable entity can be scheduled for meetings (as a person) or for use (as a resource). For a scheduling system to be able to usefully manage the schedule it needs specific information.
At the very least there needs to be some form of calendar user address. It's useful to know whether requests can be auto accepted if the slot is available.

figure.preamble: Building on the previous example we'll make Jack schedulable.
figure.artwork: BEGIN:VCARD VERSION:4.0 UID:urn:uuid:4fbe8971-0bc3-424c-9c26-36c3e1eff6b1 FN:J. Doe N:Doe;J.;;; EMAIL:jdoe@example.edu TEL;VALUE=uri:tel:+1-555-555-5555 OBJECTCLASS:eduperson NICKNAME:Jack ORGDN: dc=example, dc=edu AFFILIATION;TYPE=primary:faculty AFFILIATION;TYPE=scoped:faculty@cs.example.edu OBJECTCLASS:schedulable CALADRURI:jdoe@example.edu AUTOSCHEDULE:ACCEPT-IF-FREE END:VCARD

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: As this document only defines a schema related property and does not refer to the actual storage mechanism itself, no special security considerations are required as part of this document.
